scenarioDescription:
The HD 217107 Exoplanetary System


Overview

HD 217107 is a star with 1 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.11 times its radius. It is located 65.43 light years away from the solar system.

HD 217107 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the HD 217107 system


HD 217107 b

HD 217107 b was discovered by the Lick Observatory observatory, in 1999-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 217107 b is 413.400 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 217107 b is 13.600 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 217107 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


HD 217107 c

HD 217107 c was discovered by the Lick Observatory observatory, in 2005-10, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 5.32 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of HD 217107 c is 826.800 times the mass of Earth. The radius of HD 217107 c is 13.200 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, HD 217107 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system HD 217107, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the Lick Observatory.
name: HD 217107 - System With 2 Exolanets
